Once the audit trail functionality has been activated, the System must track events without manual intervention, and store in the audit trail information about them.

The System must ensure that audit trail data is available for inspection on request, so that a specific event can be identified and all related data made accessible, and that this can be achieved by authorised external personnel who have little or no familiarity with the system.

The Configure/Editors menu item shall provide an interface for the user to enter editor configuration information.
The user shall be able to initiate processes from an interface provided by the HATS-GUI.
The HATS-GUI shall interact with the HOST OS to find files in directories.

The GUI shall allow the user to create, modify, copy, or delete applications or files regardless of the current status of HATS-SML.
The HATS-GUI shall provide any other details related to the failure that are available from the Host OS.
The HATS-GUI shall suggest a file name for the user whenever it prompts the user to enter a file name.
When a user selects the File/Edit menu item, the HATS-GUI shall request that the operating system start a process and load that process with the editor specified by the application configuration.

The Clarus system shall be able to access in-situ environmental observations from data collectors.
The Clarus system shall be able to access remotely sensed environmental observations from data collectors.
The Clarus system shall accept environmental data derived from images.
The Clarus system shall accept surface condition data derived from surface images.
The Clarus system shall acquire and disseminate National Weather Service (NWS) watches, warnings, and advisories.
The Clarus system shall accept environmental data from transit vehicles.
The Clarus system shall not modify original observations.
The Clarus system shall be able to restrict environmental data publication based on source.
The Clarus system shall record statistics about its operation.
The Clarus system shall acquire, process, and disseminate surface data.
The Clarus system shall accept only observations that include location, timeframe, and source metadata.
The Clarus system shall accept only observations of known measurement types and units.
The Clarus system shall allow service providers to select specific desired data sets.
The Clarus system shall respond to queries for environmental data from the available data.
The Clarus system shall allow users to create a data subscription request.
The Clarus system shall use software that implements industry accepted standard interfaces.
The Clarus system shall be able to notify subscribers when data sets become available.
The Clarus system shall disseminate data using standard Internet protocols.
The Clarus system shall support 470 million current observations.
The Clarus system shall be able to collect data from sources within 5 minutes of them becoming available.
The Clarus system shall be able to receive all reported environmental data during a fifteen minute time interval.
The Clarus system shall accept data only from approved sources.
The Clarus program shall establish data sharing agreements with all participating sources of environmental data.
The Clarus program shall provide for customer service.

The DUAP Input Services shall be able to collect Clarus weather data as enumerated in APPENDIX D -Weather Data Elements from Clarus.
The DUAP System shall collect roadway traffic data.
The DUAP Input Services shall be able to collect roadway traffic data from the RCOC system using the RCOC system interface.
The DUAP Input Services shall be able to collect traffic data from the Detroit TMC system using the Detroit TMC interface.
The DUAP Input Services shall be able to collect traffic data from the Statewide TMC system using the Statewide TMC interface.
The DUAP Input Services shall be able to collect road condition data from Traffic Management Systems (TMS) using the TMS interface.
The DUAP System shall cache data only if the data record associates the data with its source, a georeferenced location, and a timestamp.

Peering Agent acts as a policy-driven resource discovery module for establishing negotiations.
Peering Agent exchanges policy, resource information, and service requirements with external Peering Agent.
Peering Agent is used as a conduit by the mediator to establish negotiations with Peering Agent of other peers and to acquire resources from them.
If the user requests can not be accepted according the provider policies, service requirements are not passed to the local Peering Agent.
Mediator works in conjunction with the Peering Agent to establish negotiation.
Local Peering Agent in conjunction with the mediator interacts with external Peering Agent through inter-Peering Agent communication protocol.
Interaction protocols between Peering Agent are identified.
If any of the termination condition holds, the local Peering Agent disbands or re-arranges the peering arrangement.

Director: A member of the Construction Junction staff who can perform the same Inventory Management functions as a Manager, plus view, create, modify and delete Inventory Management users.

Customer Service Representative: A member of the Construction Junction staff who works in the customer service desk and performs specific tasks such as constituent and member database management, item returns processing, creating drop-off acquisitions, and others.
Sales Associate: A member of the Construction Junction staff who processes purchases by Construction Junction customers.
Donor: An individual or organization who donates items to the Construction Junction inventory and receives a tax deduction for doing so.
Consigner: An individual who donates items to Construction Junction under consignment.

The Business Architecture defines the business strategy, governance, organization, and key business processes.
